Tech professional and entrepreneur. Product and project management expert. Currently leading development teams at Riot Games.
Mar 25

Accomplishing more by doing less

How limiting work in progress can help you accomplish more? This contradictory approach might be the best strategy to help you deliver.

When you’re working on a young market, where things are unknown and work is anything but predictable, there are many different paths you can follow.

Starting something isn’t an accomplishment. Every journey starts with a first step, but to actually have success in life you have complete things. It doesn’t matter if it’s a project, a family, or a business. Starting anything is relatively easy — and it has little value. It’s finishing that matters. Growing, accomplishing and achieving results. In a business, that means delivering value to your customers, employees, and shareholders.

As Apple CEO Tim Cook explained, one of the core principles Steve Jobs instilled in the company is the need to stay focused on doing only what you do best. “It’s easy to add, it’s hard to stay focused,” he said. “And so the hardest decisions we make are all the things not to work on.”

Focus isn’t saying yes do the things you decided to do, but saying no to the other thousand things you could be doing but decided not to.

If you look at very successful people you’ll notice one thing in common: the all do one thing, and one thing only. Beethoven composed. Picasso painted.

To be good at something you need focus. In “Outliers,” Gladwell contends that early access to getting 10,000 hours of practice allowed the Beatles to become the greatest band in history — thanks to playing all-night shows in Hamburg — and Bill Gates to become one of the richest dudes around — thanks to using a computer since his teen years.

The principle holds that 10,000 hours of deliberate practice are needed to become world-class in any field. When psychologists talk about deliberate practice, they mean practicing in a way that pushes your skill set as much as possible.

No matter if you want to master a craft or just deliver your job well, you’ll see how focus is key to grow and accomplish more.

When it comes to anything important in life, more is never better. Better is better.

I know all of this sounds very inspiring, but I’d like to show you how science and math backup these ideas very well.

Teams and work systems

The study of lean manufacturing and frameworks like Kanban, present some very important discoveries that show the effects of having too much work in progress.

Every team is a work system, and therefore it can be analyzed under some characteristics and metrics well know by industrial production processes. Given that, it’s important we understand a few concepts and behaviors that defines a work system:

Capacity

Capacity is defined as the maximum throughput of a work system — or in simple words — the amount of things a team can deliver in a given time.

For a factory, the capacity is the throughput rate that drives the idle time on the bottleneck to zero. For a software development team, the amount of story points the team can deliver during a sprint. For an editorial team, the amount of articles the team can write in a week. You got the idea.

The challenge comes when demand is higher than capacity, and there’s usually four things you can do:

  1. Deny the demand. As an example, during your annual strategic planning you could decide not to do a certain project due to the lack of team bandwidth or budget;
  2. Defer the demand to a future where there is capacity in the system;
  3. Increase system capacity permanently by hiring a new person to the team;
  4. Increase system capacity temporarily by outsourcing work to a vendor.

Cycle time

Cycle time is the total time required to produce a product or a feature, from entering the factory to leaving the factory. Imagine it as the total time spent from the moment you touch a piece of work to the moment you deliver it.

Cycle time includes time actually spent processing, producing, and also time spent waiting in a queue (imagine a feature that has been developed and is waiting to be tested).

Work in Progress

Work in progress (WIP) is the average number of units in production, or simply the number of things you’re working on simultaneously. WIP includes every work that is not waiting to be worked on, nor is done.

Throughput

The is the average output rate of a work system. In software development teams throughput is usually measured as velocity, the average amount of story points a team deliver every sprint.

Little’s Law

The relationship between cycle time and WIP was first documented in 1961 by J. D. C. Little. Little’s Law states that at a given WIP level, the ratio of WIP to cycle time equals throughput, as shown in the formulas below:

That means that for a team with constant throughput, WIP and cycle time are proportional. That leads to a conclusion: the higher the WIP, the longer the cycle time and the lower the throughput.

In plain English, that means:

The more things you try to do at the same time, the longer you’ll take the complete them, and the less you’ll deliver.

It’s important to notice we’re not taking variability into account here, which happens to be very true for any knowledge work such as software development, writing or art. Cycle time increases with variability and affects throughput.

In business and life, it’s definitely worthy to pursue the benefits of doing less in a world that has increasingly embraced more — more desire, more activity, more things, more exhaustion.

Remember, less isn’t about doing nothing. Less is about focus.
